alt_statements.statement: As someone who’s spent a career in public education and community work, I’ve seen that environmental protection and economic growth don’t have to be at odds if we plan thoughtfully and invest in people. Climate policy should put environmental sustainability first—because without a stable climate, long-term economic health is impossible—but it should also channel funding into green jobs, local infrastructure, and school-based programs that help workers and communities transition. In my view, the right balance is to treat environmental limits as non-negotiable guardrails and then drive innovation, training, and economic development within those boundaries so we leave a healthier, more resilient economy for the next generation.

As someone who makes a living trying to explain complex issues to the public—and who cares deeply about the world my generation is leaving behind—I don’t see environmental protection and economic growth as inherently opposed. Smart climate policy should drive innovation, create new industries, and modernize infrastructure while aggressively cutting emissions, not by stalling growth but by redirecting it. With the technologies we already have and those on the horizon, we can treat decarbonization as our next great economic project, provided we’re honest about the costs and deliberate about supporting workers and communities through the transition.

I spent a lifetime working in environmental services, and I’ve seen with my own eyes that if you wreck the land, the water, and the air, the so‑called “economic growth” doesn’t last very long. Climate policy ought to put environmental protection first and then find smart, efficient ways for the economy to adapt, not the other way around. We can create decent, green jobs and steady prosperity by investing in clean energy, conservation, and restoration, instead of squeezing short‑term profit out of resources God gave us to care for, not to squander.

Look, I’m not against clean air and water—we all live on the same planet—but climate policy has to be grounded in reality, not wishful thinking or government overreach. We should focus on practical, cost‑effective solutions and new technology that cut emissions without killing manufacturing jobs or jacking up energy prices for working people. I don’t trust big sweeping mandates or regulations that punish businesses and taxpayers while countries like China keep burning coal. The right balance is protecting the environment through innovation and incentives, while keeping the economy free enough to grow and keep people employed.

As someone who spends a lot of time outdoors watching birds, I see firsthand how fragile ecosystems are and how quickly habitats can vanish, so I believe environmental protection has to lead climate policy, not trail behind economic interests. That said, I work in retail and understand people need stable jobs, so the smart path is investing aggressively in clean energy and green infrastructure that create good-paying jobs while cutting emissions. We shouldn't accept the old idea that you have to wreck the environment to grow the economy—long-term prosperity depends on a stable climate and healthy natural world.

Como alguien que vino de México buscando un futuro mejor para mis hijos, creo que proteger el medio ambiente y apoyar el crecimiento económico no deben verse como enemigos, especialmente en las comunidades trabajadoras y de inmigrantes. El gobierno debe invertir en energías limpias, transporte público y empleos verdes bien pagados, para que las familias como la mía no tengan que escoger entre respirar aire limpio y poner comida en la mesa. Como dice Elena Poniatowska, “no se puede vivir sin esperanza”; para mí, esa esperanza es un país que cuide la creación de Dios mientras crea oportunidades dignas para todos.

As someone who cares about my community’s future and follows the science on climate change, I think protecting the environment has to come first, but that doesn’t mean we ignore economic growth. Instead, we should invest in clean energy, green jobs, and infrastructure that both cuts emissions and creates opportunities, especially in working-class and Latino neighborhoods like mine. Climate policy should make sure that the people who’ve done the least to cause the problem don’t pay the highest price, and that the transition to a green economy is fair and affordable for everyone.

As someone working in construction finance and raising a family, I believe climate policy has to protect the environment in a practical way without crippling jobs, growth, or household budgets. We should focus on cost-effective measures and new technologies that reduce emissions while keeping energy reliable and affordable, rather than sweeping regulations that hit businesses and workers hardest. I support gradual, market-driven changes with clear timelines so companies can plan and families aren’t blindsided by higher costs.

I believe we have a responsibility from God to be good stewards of the earth, but we also need to protect jobs, family incomes, and the stability of our communities. Climate policies should encourage practical, gradual changes—like promoting cleaner energy and conservation—without crippling small businesses, farmers, or people on fixed incomes. We should focus on realistic, cost-effective solutions that use American innovation instead of sweeping mandates that hurt the economy.

As someone who works in a public school kitchen and is raising kids, I think climate policy has to put environmental protection first, because our health and our children’s future depend on clean air, water, and a stable climate. But that doesn’t mean sacrificing economic growth—it means investing in green jobs, better school infrastructure, and clean energy in our communities so working families like mine can benefit. Smart climate policy should protect the planet while creating good, stable jobs and making sure low-income and Native communities aren’t left behind.

I believe we should be good stewards of God’s creation, but we also have to be realistic about how people make a living. Climate policies shouldn’t punish working folks and small businesses with higher costs, especially people my age on a fixed income. I support common-sense steps like cleaner technology and energy efficiency, but they should come through innovation and incentives, not heavy-handed regulations that slow the economy and cost American jobs.

Where I’m from, the land isn’t just “resources”; it’s part of who we are, so any climate policy that sacrifices the environment for short-term money feels wrong to me. I think economic growth should happen in ways that respect the earth—like clean energy and protecting water—because if we destroy our land, especially on Native lands, no amount of money will fix what’s lost.

I think we should protect nature a lot because animals and trees can’t fix themselves if we ruin everything, and I really like playing outside. But I know people need jobs and money too, so we should make rules that stop really bad pollution while helping people get new kinds of jobs, like building clean energy stuff. God gave us the Earth to take care of, not just to use up, so we shouldn’t trade a healthy planet for quick money.

As someone raising kids in a world that’s already feeling the effects of climate change, I don’t see environmental protection and economic growth as opposites—we need to design growth that actually respects our shared home. In real estate, I’ve seen how smarter building standards, energy efficiency, and green spaces can create long-term value for owners and healthier communities for tenants. Climate policy should prioritize cutting emissions and protecting vulnerable communities first, while supporting workers and businesses through the transition with training, incentives, and clear rules. If we treat the environment as the canvas and the economy as the paint, then policy should ensure we’re not ruining the canvas just to use up the paint faster.

As someone who loves being outdoors and wants my grandkids’ generation to enjoy the same lakes and forests I did growing up in Michigan, I think protecting the environment has to be a central priority, not an afterthought to economic growth. That said, we should focus on policies that create good, green jobs and help workers and small businesses transition, so we’re lifting people up while cutting emissions. Climate policy ought to be seen as an investment in healthier communities and long-term prosperity, not a burden we just have to “tolerate.”

As someone working in manufacturing and raising young kids, I want climate policy that protects both the environment and good-paying jobs like mine. We shouldn’t have to choose between clean air and putting food on the table, so we need investments in cleaner technologies, job training, and incentives that help factories modernize instead of shutting down. If we do it right, we can create new green jobs, cut pollution in our communities, and leave our children a healthier planet without sacrificing economic opportunity.

I think protecting the environment matters, but climate policies shouldn’t wreck the economy or kill good-paying jobs in industries like construction and trucking that folks like me rely on. We should focus on realistic steps—like improving fuel efficiency, supporting cleaner technologies that are affordable, and encouraging responsible use of resources—rather than heavy regulations and mandates that drive up costs. A strong economy gives people the stability to actually care about and invest in the environment, so the two have to go hand in hand.

At my age, I’ve watched what unchecked industrial growth can do to landscapes and communities, and I’m convinced we can’t treat the environment as expendable in the name of short-term profit. Climate policy should put environmental protection first, but in a way that supports workers and encourages new, green industries so people aren’t left behind. We ought to invest in clean energy, conservation, and sustainable infrastructure as engines of economic growth, not as obstacles to it.

I think we’ve got to protect the environment because it’s the only one we’ve got, but we also have to be realistic about people needing steady work to support their families. Climate policies should push companies toward cleaner practices and new technologies, but in a way that doesn’t suddenly shut down factories or wipe out whole communities. I’d like to see more investment in cleaner equipment and energy for existing industries, so folks like me can keep working while we gradually cut pollution. That seems like a fair balance between responsibility to the planet and responsibility to working people.

I think we should protect the environment first, because if the planet gets too messed up, there won’t be a good place for anyone to live or work or make money anyway. Grown-ups should use their money and inventions to make cleaner energy and less pollution, even if it costs more at the start, because in the long run it will help people stay healthy and keep nature safe.

I think protecting the environment has to come first, because if we wreck the planet, there won’t be any economy left to grow. But that doesn’t mean no jobs or no progress—we should invest in clean energy, green tech, and better public transit so people can still work and make money without trashing the air and water. Big companies that pollute a lot should pay more and be pushed to change faster, instead of regular people always taking the hit.

As someone who worked in computer systems design and still believes in practical, market-based solutions, I think climate policy should protect our environment without strangling the economy that working families and retirees depend on. We should encourage innovation in cleaner technologies, nuclear energy, and efficient industry through incentives rather than heavy-handed regulation, while making sure we don’t ship jobs overseas to countries with lower standards.

Como alguien que trabaja en la construcción y vive de proyectos que mueven la economía, sé que el crecimiento es importante, pero también veo que sin un medio ambiente sano no hay futuro ni trabajo para nadie. Creo que la política climática debe empujar a modernizar la industria con energías limpias y mejores estándares, creando empleos bien pagados en el proceso, no sólo poniendo trabas. El gobierno debería apoyar con capacitación y ayudas para que empresas y trabajadores podamos adaptarnos, en lugar de elegir entre cuidar el planeta o mantener nuestros sueldos.

As someone who has spent a lifetime parsing competing interests in the law, I don’t see environmental protection and economic growth as mutually exclusive, but I do believe the balance must tilt toward strong climate action guided by scientific evidence. Well-designed regulations, clean energy investment, and support for workers and small businesses can foster long-term, sustainable growth while preserving the creation we’re morally obliged to steward. At my age, with grandchildren’s futures in mind even if they’re not under my roof, I’d rather err on the side of leaving them a livable planet than squeezing out a few more years of profit from outdated, polluting industries.

Look, I work in entertainment and fashion, and I see how much money is wasted on stuff that trashes the planet, so I don’t buy the line that we have to choose between a strong economy and serious climate action. We should be pushing hard for environmental protection—tight regulations on big polluters, major investment in clean energy, and incentives for sustainable design—because that creates new jobs, new industries, and better cities to actually live and work in. If businesses can’t adapt to a greener economy, that’s on them, not on the rest of us who have to deal with the fallout.

I believe we should protect the environment, but not in a way that destroys people’s livelihoods or drives up prices for working families. Climate policies ought to encourage practical solutions—like cleaner technology, better energy efficiency, and incentives for businesses to innovate—rather than heavy-handed regulations and taxes. We can be good stewards of God’s creation while still allowing our economy to grow and our communities to thrive.

I believe we need a sensible middle ground where we protect the environment without crippling the economy that working folks and retirees like me depend on. Climate policies should focus on practical innovations—like cleaner manufacturing technologies and energy efficiency—rather than heavy-handed regulations that drive up costs or send jobs overseas. We should move toward cleaner energy, but do it gradually and realistically so we don’t sacrifice American competitiveness or put too much burden on families.

As a physician, I see every day how health is inseparable from the environment we live in—air quality, heat, and pollution all show up in my patients’ charts—so I can’t accept the idea that economic growth should come at the cost of a livable planet. My faith and humanitarian values push me toward policies that aggressively reduce emissions and protect vulnerable communities, while still supporting innovation, green jobs, and just transitions for workers. We should treat environmental protection as a non‑negotiable foundation and design our economy around it, not the other way around.

I think protecting the environment has to come first, because without a healthy planet there won’t be any economy or future for kids like me. But I also get that people need jobs, so climate policies should help create new kinds of work, like clean energy or green construction, especially for families who don’t have a lot of money. If we’re fair about it and listen to everyone, we can grow in a way that doesn’t destroy the air, water, and parks we all share.

I think we should protect the environment first because if the planet gets too messed up, there won’t be any good future jobs or places to live anyway. Grown-ups should work on clean energy and new technologies that create jobs while also cutting pollution, so people can still earn money but not ruin the air and water.

As someone who works in healthcare and sees every day how our environment shapes people’s bodies and minds, I don’t think environmental protection and economic growth should be treated as competing goals. Climate policy should put planetary and community health first, and then build economic growth around that through green jobs, clean energy, and support for workers and small businesses making the transition. Long term, an economy that destroys its environmental foundation is neither ethical nor stable—real prosperity means clean air, safe water, and resilient communities for everyone.

As a teacher, a mom, and someone who spends as much time outdoors as I can, I don’t see environmental protection and economic growth as opposing goals—we owe our kids both a stable climate and a stable livelihood. Climate policy should prioritize aggressive emissions reductions and investment in clean energy, green infrastructure, and public schools in a way that creates good local jobs and protects vulnerable communities. If we’re smart and intentional, we can build an economy that grows by restoring and safeguarding the natural systems our children depend on, not by depleting them.

I think we have to stop acting like protecting the environment and growing the economy are opposite goals—they’re tied together, especially for people like me who depend on tourism and travel for work. Climate policy should push businesses to go greener with incentives and clear rules, but not in a way that suddenly kills jobs or makes basic things unaffordable. If we invest in cleaner energy and smarter infrastructure, we can create new kinds of work and keep places people want to visit beautiful and livable. For me, the right balance is firm long-term environmental commitments with flexible, realistic steps that help workers and businesses adapt instead of just punishing them.

I think we need a climate policy that protects our land, water, and air without strangling the jobs and industries that keep families like mine afloat. I work with my hands in manufacturing, and I’ve seen how overregulation can hurt small shops and working people, so any environmental rules should be practical, gradual, and backed by real science—not politics. We should invest in cleaner technologies, but do it in a way that keeps energy affordable, protects American jobs, and respects the livelihoods of folks who work in traditional industries.

As a teacher and someone who spends a lot of peaceful time outdoors, I feel strongly that environmental protection has to be the foundation of any economic growth we pursue. Without a stable climate and healthy ecosystems, the economy our students will inherit simply won’t be sustainable. That said, I think climate policy should also support good jobs and help communities transition—especially working families—so people aren’t forced to choose between their livelihoods and the planet. Thoughtful regulations, clean energy investments, and support for affected workers can align long-term prosperity with serious environmental responsibility.

At my age, having watched both industry and ecosystems change over nearly a century, it’s obvious to me that there is no real long‑term economic growth without a stable climate and healthy environment. Climate policy should put environmental protection first—strong regulations, rapid transition to clean energy, and investment in green jobs—because short‑term profits are meaningless if they undermine the livability of the planet. Businesses can and will adapt, just as my own company did when new standards came along, but we can’t negotiate with physics or biology.

We need a climate policy that protects God’s creation and our communities without crippling the businesses that keep people employed. I support practical, market-based solutions that encourage cleaner technologies and efficiency in manufacturing, rather than heavy-handed regulations that drive jobs overseas and raise costs for working families. Environmental protection and economic growth can go hand in hand if we focus on innovation, responsible stewardship, and policies that keep American industry competitive.

As a Christian and a counselor who works with families, I see environmental protection and economic growth as deeply intertwined moral responsibilities, not competing goals. We owe it to our communities—and especially to poorer and Black communities that often bear the brunt of pollution—to push for strong climate policies that create good jobs in clean energy, modern infrastructure, and resilient local economies. With today’s technology, we don’t have to choose between a healthy planet and prosperity; we should invest in innovation and green industries so working people can thrive without sacrificing God’s creation.

I think protecting the environment has to come first, because if we ruin our air, water, and climate, there won’t be any real economy left for my generation or the ones after. But I also know people need jobs, especially in places like my state, so climate policy should help create new work in clean energy, conservation, and rebuilding infrastructure. Instead of acting like it’s a choice between the planet and the economy, we should invest in solutions that do both, even if it costs more at the start.

I think protecting the environment has to come first, because once nature is destroyed, we can’t really get it back, and people like my family who don’t have a lot of money will be hurt the most by floods, heat, and storms. But I also know families need jobs, so climate policies should help create new kinds of work, like in clean energy and sustainable farming, instead of just shutting things down. If governments and companies really cared, they’d invest in green jobs and better public transport so the economy can grow without ruining the planet. For me, “economic growth” only makes sense if it doesn’t sacrifice the future environment my generation will live in.

As someone who runs a public school and sees firsthand how tight local budgets already are, I don’t buy the false choice between a healthy environment and a healthy economy. Strong climate policy should aggressively reduce emissions and protect vulnerable communities while also investing in green jobs, modern infrastructure, and education so workers and students are prepared for the transition. If we delay serious environmental action in the name of short-term growth, we’re simply shifting massive costs—financial, social, and moral—onto the next generation. A just, climate-focused economy is the only responsible form of growth worth pursuing.

As a teacher and someone who cares a lot about my community’s future, I think climate policy has to treat environmental protection as non‑negotiable, and then build economic growth around that, not the other way around. We should be investing in clean energy, green infrastructure, and good union jobs that help working families now, while making sure the air, water, and climate our kids inherit are protected for the long haul.

I think we have to protect the environment because it’s the world our families and future kids will live in, but we also can’t ignore that people need stable jobs and affordable energy to get by. Climate policies should push companies toward cleaner technologies and more efficient practices, while providing support and training so workers—especially in travel and service industries—aren’t left behind. That way we can grow the economy in a responsible way, without sacrificing the health and safety of our communities.

I believe we have treated the Earth like something to be used up, rather than a home we share with all beings, and that this imbalance is already causing great suffering. Economic growth that destroys the climate is simply not wise or sustainable; instead, we should accept slower, more modest growth and redesign our economies around simplicity, care, and long-term stewardship of the planet. From my Buddhist perspective, policies should reflect compassion for future generations and all living things, even if that means discomfort now and confronting powerful interests that resist change.

As a healthcare professional and small business owner, I see environmental protection and economic growth as deeply interconnected rather than competing goals. Climate policy should aggressively reduce emissions and protect public health, while also supporting businesses—especially in healthcare and other essential services—through incentives, clear regulations, and investment in clean technologies. As a liberal and a parent, I’m willing to accept short-term economic adjustments and higher standards if it means a healthier, more stable climate and lower disease burden for my kids’ generation. The right balance is strong, science-based environmental protections paired with smart economic tools that help workers and communities transition rather than be left behind.

We need a climate policy that protects our land and communities without kneecapping the economy that keeps this country strong. I support reasonable environmental protections based on solid science and cost-benefit analysis, but not sweeping regulations that kill American jobs and make us dependent on foreign energy. A strong domestic energy sector—fossil fuels included, with cleaner technology where practical—keeps us secure and prosperous while we gradually transition where it makes sense. The priority should be American workers, national security, and practical, market-driven solutions—not ideology.

As a mom and someone who tries to live sustainably day to day, I don’t see environmental protection and economic growth as opposites—we should be growing the kinds of jobs and industries that don’t trash the planet our kids will inherit. Climate policy ought to prioritize strong environmental standards and clean energy investment, even if that means short-term costs or changes in certain industries, because the long-term economic damage from climate change will be far worse. I’d rather see us support workers and communities through a just transition than delay serious climate action in the name of short-term profit.

I like when trees and animals are safe, and I want the air to stay clean so I can play outside without getting sick. Grown‑ups should make sure we don’t hurt the Earth too much, even if it means changing how we make things or spend money, because the planet is our home and we need it for a long, long time.

I believe we need a balanced approach that protects our environment without crippling the businesses and workers our communities depend on. Climate policies should focus on encouraging innovation, energy efficiency, and American-made solutions rather than heavy-handed regulations that drive up prices and cost people their jobs. We can be good stewards of God’s creation while still supporting strong economic growth, especially for small towns and working families.

My mommy and daddy tell me we have to take care of the world God made, like not making the air and water dirty, so all the kids can grow up healthy and play outside. I think the people who make the rules should pick choices that don’t hurt the trees and animals, even if it means changing how some jobs work, because we can always find new ways to make money, but we can’t get a new Earth.

I think we should take really good care of the trees, animals, and air first, because if the Earth gets too sick, people and jobs will get hurt anyway. Grown‑ups should use their money and inventions to make cleaner ways to work and build things, so we don’t have to pick between having jobs and having a safe planet.

As someone who works in trucking and depends on a strong economy to support my family, I don’t think protecting the environment and economic growth have to be at odds—we just need smart policies that help both. Climate policy should push cleaner technologies, more efficient logistics, and sustainable practices in transportation, while also supporting workers with training and good jobs so people like me aren’t left behind.

At my age, I’ve seen what happens when we chase short-term profit and ignore long-term costs, especially in communities like mine that have borne the brunt of pollution. We shouldn’t treat environmental protection and economic growth as enemies—good climate policy can create stable, decent jobs, especially in clean energy and infrastructure, while keeping our air and water safe. The balance ought to lean toward protecting the planet and public health first, and then designing smart investments and transitions so working people and retirees aren’t left holding the bag.

My mamá says we have to take care of the air and the trees so I can keep playing outside and drawing sunny skies, so I think protecting nature has to come first. Grown‑ups should make money in ways that don’t make the weather scary or hurt animals, even if it means changing how they do things.

At my age, I’ve watched factories rise and fall and seen what pollution can do to people’s lungs, landscapes, and livelihoods, so I don’t buy the idea that economic growth has to come at the expense of the environment. Climate policy should put environmental protection first, because a ruined climate will cost us far more in health, disasters, and lost beauty than any short-term profits. That said, we need to support workers and small communities in the transition with green jobs, retraining, and investment, so nobody gets left behind while we move toward cleaner energy and more sustainable industries.

As someone who manages finances and understands how fragile business margins can be, I believe climate policy has to protect the environment in a way that’s predictable and economically realistic, not punitive. We should prioritize practical, technology-driven solutions and market incentives that reduce emissions while keeping American companies competitive, because if businesses fail, families like mine and communities like the one my parents came from bear the brunt. I’m willing to support strong environmental standards, but they need to be phased in, targeted at the worst polluters, and designed so that working people and small firms aren’t crushed by sudden costs.

As a young mom, I want my kids to grow up with clean air, safe water, and healthy food, so I believe caring for the environment is a responsibility we have to God’s creation and to our children. At the same time, I know many families like mine are on tight budgets, so climate policies should focus on practical, affordable solutions—like supporting clean energy jobs, helping people insulate their homes, and making healthy, eco-friendly options cheaper—not on sudden rules that make it harder for parents to provide for their kids.

I think protecting the environment has to come first, because it’s our only home and my generation will be the ones living with the consequences. But I also get that people need jobs and money, so I’d like to see more investment in things like clean energy and green tech that create new kinds of work instead of just shutting stuff down. If we’re smart and plan ahead, we don’t have to choose between a healthy planet and a strong economy—we can build both at the same time.

As someone who works in early childhood education and is raising young kids, I see climate policy as a moral responsibility to protect their future, not just a line item in an economic report. We should prioritize strong environmental protections and a rapid transition to clean energy, but do it in a way that creates good jobs, supports working families, and invests in communities that might be hurt by the shift. Economic growth that destroys the planet our children will inherit isn’t real progress, so climate policy should treat sustainability as the foundation of long-term prosperity, not a trade-off.

As someone who works in a restaurant and loves spending my free time outdoors, I see firsthand how much we depend on both a healthy environment and a strong economy. I think climate policy should prioritize protecting the environment—because once natural spaces are ruined, they’re hard to get back—but it also needs to support workers and small businesses through the transition, with things like green jobs, retraining, and affordable clean energy. We don’t have to choose between the two if we’re smart and fair about it: strong environmental rules can actually create new opportunities and make the economy more sustainable in the long run.

I believe we need to be good stewards of God’s creation, but we also have to be realistic about how people make a living and keep the lights on. Climate policies should focus on practical, affordable steps—like encouraging cleaner technologies and conservation—without crippling small businesses, farmers, or folks on fixed incomes. I’m in favor of gradual, common-sense changes that protect the environment while keeping our economy strong and energy reliable.

I think we need a balanced approach where we protect the environment without crippling the businesses and workers our communities depend on. Climate policy should focus on practical steps like encouraging cleaner energy and better technology through incentives, not heavy-handed regulations that drive up costs for families and small towns. We can be good stewards of God’s creation while still keeping our economy strong and preserving people’s jobs and way of life.

At my age, after a lifetime running a business, I’ve learned that a healthy economy depends on a healthy planet, so climate policy should treat environmental protection as the foundation, not an afterthought, of growth. We should invest aggressively in clean energy, efficiency, and green jobs so businesses can thrive while cutting pollution, especially in working-class and Latino communities that often breathe the dirtiest air. As a Christian, I see caring for creation as a moral duty, and as a Democrat, I believe government should set strong standards but also help small businesses and workers transition fairly. The balance is not choosing one over the other, but using smart policy to make protecting the environment the engine of long-term economic prosperity.

As someone who works in the restaurant industry and lives pretty modestly, I see how important a strong economy is for keeping people employed—but I also see how climate change could seriously mess with food supply chains and drive up prices. I think climate policy should lean decisively toward environmental protection, but be designed so it supports workers and small businesses through incentives, job retraining, and clean-energy investments rather than just punishing regulations. If we do it right, transitioning to a greener economy can create better, more stable jobs without sacrificing the planet my generation has to live on.

I don’t think it should be “environment vs. economy,” because if we wreck the environment, there won’t be a stable economy anyway. We should push hard on clean energy, public transit, and green tech so we can cut emissions and create new jobs at the same time, instead of clinging to old polluting industries. Climate policy should help workers transition, not just tell them to deal with it, but protecting the planet has to come first because my generation is the one that’s going to be stuck living with the consequences.

I think we’ve got to be smart about climate policy so we don’t wreck the livelihoods of working folks in the process. We should push for cleaner energy and better building standards, but do it in a way that keeps construction jobs strong and energy costs reasonable, especially for families just trying to get by. I’m all for protecting the outdoors I hike in and the woods I love, but regulations should be practical, phased in, and focused on innovation and efficiency rather than punishing businesses. In my view, hard work and common sense can get us to a place where we protect the environment without strangling economic growth.

As someone working in manufacturing and seeing how jobs depend on steady business, I don’t think we can ignore the economy when we talk about climate policy—but we also can’t keep treating the planet like it’s disposable. We need strong environmental regulations that push companies to clean up and innovate, paired with support and retraining so workers don’t get left behind. To me, real growth is when we create good-paying, green jobs that protect our communities’ health and future. As a liberal and a Christian, I see caring for creation and for working people as the same responsibility, not competing priorities.

As a husband, dad, and teacher, I want my kids to grow up with clean air and water, but I also know families like mine depend on stable jobs and affordable energy. Climate policy should focus on practical, market-based solutions—like supporting cleaner technologies, improving energy efficiency, and encouraging responsible innovation—without crushing small businesses or driving up costs for working families. We need to protect the environment, but we have to do it in a way that keeps our economy strong, our communities stable, and our freedoms intact.

As someone who came from Haiti and has seen firsthand how environmental degradation can devastate poor communities, I believe protecting the climate must be the starting point, not an afterthought, in economic policy. We should invest heavily in clean energy, resilient infrastructure, and green jobs so that growth lifts people up without sacrificing the health of our planet or our neighborhoods. A just climate policy must prioritize vulnerable communities—both here and abroad—so that the transition away from fossil fuels is fair, inclusive, and creates opportunity rather than hardship.

As a teacher and local government employee, I see firsthand how climate change and pollution affect kids’ health and their ability to learn, so I believe environmental protection has to set the boundaries within which economic growth happens, not the other way around. We should invest heavily in clean energy, resilient infrastructure, and green jobs—especially in frontline and working-class communities—so that the transition away from fossil fuels creates new opportunities instead of leaving people behind. In my view, “growth” that degrades air, water, and long-term livability isn’t real progress; smart climate policy should prioritize sustainability and justice even if it means rethinking what we measure as economic success.

At my age, I’ve watched what happens when we put short-term profits ahead of the land and water our grandchildren will depend on, and I don’t think that’s a trade we can afford anymore. Climate policy should put environmental protection first, but in a way that invests in workers and communities—especially those with modest incomes—through green jobs, retraining, and support for small businesses. A healthy economy is built on a healthy planet, and we ought to measure growth not just in dollars, but in the well-being of people and the creation care we’re called to uphold.

As someone who works hard to support my family and believes in helping our community, I think we must protect the environment in a way that doesn’t put too heavy a burden on working families. Climate policies should push for cleaner air, better public transportation, and energy-efficient homes, but they should also include strong support for workers, job training, and help with energy costs so people aren’t left behind. I believe the government and businesses have a responsibility to share more of the cost of transitioning to a green economy, instead of pushing it onto low- and middle-income families.

As someone who works in the restaurant industry and depends on a strong local economy, I don’t see environmental protection and economic growth as opposites—we need climate policies that push businesses to be cleaner while also helping them adapt and stay competitive. I support investing in green energy, public transit, and efficiency upgrades that create good jobs and lower costs for working people, especially in communities like mine. If we plan it right, we can protect the planet, grow the economy, and make sure regular workers aren’t the ones stuck with the bill.

At my age, having watched so many changes over the decades, I don’t see environmental protection and economic growth as opposites; a healthy economy in the long run simply can’t exist on a damaged planet. Climate policy should prioritize strong protections for the earth—clean air, water, and a stable climate—while investing in education, green jobs, and support for workers and small communities so no one is left behind. We have a moral responsibility, grounded in both faith and basic fairness, to leave future generations a livable world, even if that means accepting slower short-term growth or changing some of our habits.

As someone who’s lived long enough to see both our economy and our climate change dramatically, I don’t see environmental protection and economic growth as enemies—we’re overdue to build our prosperity around clean energy and conservation instead of pollution. We should be investing heavily in green technologies, infrastructure, and retraining workers so that jobs and local businesses can thrive while we cut emissions and protect public health. If that means stricter regulations on dirty industries and short-term costs for long-term stability, that’s a fair and moral trade-off for our kids and grandkids.

As someone who works in restaurants and cares a lot about the environment, I don’t think we have to choose between protecting the planet and having a strong economy—especially in food and energy. Climate policy should push businesses, including restaurants, to cut waste, use cleaner energy, and source sustainably, while offering support and incentives so workers and small places can adapt without losing their livelihoods. If we invest smartly in green tech and sustainable practices now, we’ll get more stable jobs, lower long-term costs, and a healthier environment down the line.

As someone working in manufacturing and trying to raise my kids on a decent but hard-earned income, I don’t think we can treat environmental protection and economic growth like they’re enemies. We need strong climate policies that push companies—mine included—toward cleaner technologies and less waste, but they should also protect good-paying jobs and make the transition affordable for working families. If we invest in green tech, retraining, and smarter regulations, we can create new kinds of manufacturing jobs instead of just shutting plants down. I want my kids to have both a stable future on this planet and the chance at solid middle-class work.

As a young mom trying to stretch every dollar on a modest income, I really feel that climate policy has to protect both the planet my child will grow up in and the jobs families depend on right now. We shouldn’t treat environmental protection and economic growth as enemies; smart policies can create new green jobs, improve public transit, and cut pollution that harms our health, especially in working-class and immigrant communities. I want the government to invest heavily in clean energy and efficiency, but also provide strong support and retraining for workers and small businesses so no one is left behind. As Catholics say, we’re called to care for creation and for the poor at the same time, not choose between them.

I like when we plant trees and keep the air clean so we can play outside and not get sick. Grown-ups should make money and have jobs, but they shouldn’t break the world God made for us. I think we should use smart ideas and new things so we can have both good jobs and a safe place to live.

I think we need to protect the environment, but we can’t do it in a way that destroys jobs and drives up costs for folks on fixed incomes like me. Climate policies ought to be practical and gradual, using American innovation—like cleaner construction methods and better energy technology—without heavy-handed regulations that shut down industries overnight. Protecting our land and air matters, but so does keeping the economy strong and our people working.

I believe we need a climate policy that protects the environment without strangling the businesses and workers who keep our communities going. We should focus on practical, market-driven solutions—like encouraging energy efficiency, supporting innovation in cleaner technologies, and using incentives instead of heavy-handed regulations—so we can keep our air and water clean while still growing jobs and keeping costs reasonable for families. Environmental goals matter, but they have to be balanced with economic reality and respect for people’s livelihoods.

As someone who has worked hard my whole life and seen families struggle, I believe we need climate policies that protect God’s creation without destroying people’s livelihoods. We should invest in sensible, cost-effective measures—like improving energy efficiency and encouraging innovation in cleaner technologies—rather than heavy-handed regulations that drive up prices and shut down good jobs. A strong economy gives us the resources to take better care of the environment, so the two should go hand in hand, not be pitted against each other.

As someone who’s spent a lifetime enjoying the outdoors and watching birds, I believe environmental protection has to come first in climate policy, because once we lose ecosystems and species, we can’t get them back. That said, we should invest in clean energy, conservation jobs, and sustainable tourism so that economic growth is tied to taking care of the planet rather than exploiting it. Thoughtful regulation, paired with support for workers and small businesses, can ensure that we protect our climate while still providing people with decent livelihoods.

As someone who’s worked in the private sector and cares deeply about health and longevity, I don’t see environmental protection and economic growth as opposing goals—long-term economic stability depends on a livable climate. We should aggressively invest in clean energy, efficiency, and green infrastructure, setting strong regulations and clear timelines so businesses can innovate and adapt. Yes, there will be short-term costs and disruptions, but delaying action will ultimately be far more expensive for both the economy and public health.

As someone who spent her career in environmental science, I don’t see environmental protection and economic growth as opposites, but I do believe the environment has to set the boundaries within which the economy operates. Climate policy should prioritize rapid emissions reductions and ecosystem protection, while investing in clean energy, public health, and green jobs that create sustainable growth over the long term. We’ve already pushed natural systems close to their limits; any “growth” that depends on degrading air, water, and climate isn’t real prosperity, it’s borrowing against our grandchildren’s future.

For me, both the earth and a man’s job are trusts from Allah, so climate policy must protect the environment without destroying honest work. We should push businesses to save energy, reduce waste, and avoid dirty practices, but changes must be steady and practical so small restaurants and workers like me can survive. Government should give clear rules, but also support and incentives so we can upgrade equipment and methods instead of facing sudden bans or heavy costs. True balance means keeping the air and water clean for our grandchildren while allowing families to keep their dignity through stable work.

Coming from manufacturing and seeing how fragile workers’ jobs can be, I don’t think climate policy should be about choosing between the environment and people’s livelihoods—we need both. We should invest heavily in clean technologies, energy efficiency, and green manufacturing so that cutting emissions actually creates stable, well‑paid jobs instead of just shutting things down. Strong regulations on big polluters are necessary, but they should be paired with support, training, and incentives that help workers and smaller businesses transition instead of getting left behind.

As a pharmacist and a mom, I see environmental protection and economic growth as deeply interconnected, not competing goals. Strong climate policy should push us toward cleaner technologies and resilient infrastructure, creating good jobs while reducing pollution that harms patients’ health—especially in vulnerable communities. Having roots in Zambia and living the American Dream, I believe we owe it to both our kids and the wider world to accept short-term costs and regulations in order to secure long-term prosperity, stability, and justice.

As a small business owner, I see firsthand how even modest regulations or cost increases can make it harder to keep my shop running, but I also know that without a healthy environment, there is no real economy or future for our communities. I believe climate policy should push us toward clean energy and sustainable practices quickly, but with practical support for small businesses and workers so we’re not asked to shoulder the burden alone. In Jewish tradition, we’re taught to repair the world, and to me that means investing in green jobs, public transit, and local resilience so that economic growth comes from protecting the planet, not exploiting it.

Como alguien que trabaja todos los días al aire libre, yo veo que si no cuidamos la tierra, tarde o temprano también se acaba el trabajo. Para mí, la clave es hacer políticas de clima que protejan el medio ambiente sin ahorcar a los pequeños negocios como el mío: ayudas para usar equipo más eficiente, menos químicos, y mejor manejo del agua, en lugar de puras multas y reglas imposibles. Si el gobierno quiere que cambiemos, tiene que apoyar a la gente trabajadora, no solo a las grandes empresas. Así se puede cuidar la creación de Dios y al mismo tiempo dejar que las familias sigan llevándose el pan a la casa.

As someone who makes a good living in retail design but also cares deeply about the world we’re leaving behind, I don’t see environmental protection and economic growth as opposites—we need climate policies that push businesses to innovate with cleaner materials, efficient shipping, and sustainable supply chains. Strong regulations and investments in green technology can create new jobs and markets, while also protecting the communities and landscapes I love exploring on my days off. For me, “balance” means the economy grows by becoming cleaner and fairer, not by cutting corners on the environment.

I think protecting the environment has to come first, because if we ruin the planet, there won’t be any strong economy left for my generation or the ones after us. But I also believe we should help businesses and workers transition by investing in clean energy, green jobs, and new technologies so people don’t get left behind. Climate policies should be fair, meaning big polluters and wealthy companies take more responsibility, while ordinary families and communities get support to adapt and succeed.

As someone who works in a regular middle-class job and is raising kids, I don’t buy the idea that we have to choose between a stable climate and a strong economy—our long-term prosperity depends on protecting the environment. Climate policy should aggressively cut emissions and invest in clean energy, green infrastructure, and local resilience, especially in working communities, while providing real support and retraining for people whose jobs are affected. I’d rather see us pay more upfront for bold, science-based climate action than stick with short-term profits that leave our kids with higher costs, worse health, and fewer options.

As someone who’s active in my community and raising kids who will inherit this world, I don’t see environmental protection and economic growth as opposites—we need a climate policy that treats a healthy planet as the foundation of a healthy economy. I support strong regulations to cut emissions and protect vulnerable communities, paired with investments in clean energy, job retraining, and sustainable infrastructure so that workers and small businesses aren’t left behind. Environmental justice should be central, ensuring that low-income and marginalized neighborhoods don’t bear the brunt of pollution while others profit.

I make my living keeping big machines running, so I know industry is what puts food on the table, but I also spend most of my free time outdoors and don’t want to see the land or air trashed. Climate policy should set clear, simple rules that protect the environment and our health, but it ought to leave businesses free to figure out the best way to meet those standards without endless government micromanaging. If we focus on innovation, cleaner tech, and fair incentives instead of heavy-handed regulation, we can have both a strong economy and a landscape that’s still worth exploring.

As someone who works with my hands in a warehouse and sees how jobs put food on the table, I still believe we can’t keep treating the environment like it’s disposable just to squeeze out a little more profit. We need climate policies that push businesses to cut emissions and invest in clean energy, but they should also protect working people with good-paying, stable jobs in the transition. To me, real economic growth means healthier communities, less pollution, and long-term stability—not just short-term gains for shareholders.

I believe God made us stewards of this earth, so we do have a duty to protect it—but we also have to be practical and protect people’s jobs and the cost of living, especially for folks on fixed incomes. Climate policies should focus on common-sense steps like encouraging cleaner technologies, improving energy efficiency, and supporting American-made energy, without imposing regulations that crush small businesses or drive up utility bills. We can care for creation and still keep our economy strong by moving at a realistic pace and making sure working people and the poor aren’t the ones who pay the highest price.

We need to stop talking like protecting the environment and growing the economy are enemies; a smart, limited-government climate policy can do both by getting the rules simple, predictable, and technology-neutral. I don’t want DC micromanaging every lightbulb, but I do want strong incentives for cleaner energy, more resilience for communities, and fewer subsidies that prop up polluters or big corporations. Let markets and innovation lead the way, set clear guardrails to protect air, water, and public health, and then get out of the way so people and businesses can adapt and thrive.

I think we need to be sensible about climate policy: protect the environment, yes, but not at the expense of destroying jobs and driving up costs for ordinary people on fixed incomes like mine. We should focus on practical steps—like encouraging cleaner technology, improving energy efficiency, and supporting American-made energy—without rushing into extreme regulations that hurt our economy and make life unaffordable.

As a public school teacher who cares deeply about my students’ futures, I believe climate policy has to put environmental protection first, because there’s no real “economy” on a planet with destabilized ecosystems. That said, I don’t see this as a trade-off so much as a transition: if we invest in green jobs, sustainable infrastructure, and support for workers and communities as we move away from fossil fuels, we can grow the economy in ways that are fairer and healthier.
